status_message:
A polio patient, Chu Maya Purja from Myagdi was falling through the cracks and seemed destined to end up as another statistic in the lengthening list of poor Nepalis neglected by the state. A visit to Women's Skills Development Organisation (WSDO) in 2003, however, turned her life around. 

Today, the 39-year-old trains other poor women like herself and helps them overcome personal and social obstacles.
link_name: Rising through the cracks | Nation| Nepali Times

status_message:
In the remote and bucolic Magar settlement of Jhirubas of Palpa district, time stands still. A wrenching seven hour ride from Tansen, the region's Magar culture has been protected till now because of its remoteness: the language, dress, architecture, farming methods, and food.

With help from the District Forest Office, villagers have converted degraded pastures into plantations of grass used for commercial broom-making. In just three short years, Jhirubas is where the country's largest broom farm is located.
link_name: Broom brings boom | Nation| Nepali Times

status_message:
Our editorial this week explains how the unseemly political barter deal that let  Lok Man Singh Karki head the CIAA did yield one desirable result though. For the first time in six years we actually have an auditor general and the NC's nominee couldn't have been a better candidate. 

Bhanu Prasad Acharya is a soft-spoken, seasoned bureaucrat known for his competence, integrity, and no-nonsense style. What a contrast to Karki, the man that the AG's office is supposed to work with to control endemic corruption.

And if Acharya is not allowed to work, or if the CIAA under Karki starts a political witch-hunt, civil society may be forced to set up a conscience-keeping body.
link_name: Watching the watchdog | Editorial| Nepali Times

status_message: Two weeks have passed since the controversial appointments to vacant constitutional bodies were ratified by the president's office on the recommendation of the Constitutional Council, but the blame game between political parties, Singha Darbar, and Shital Niwas continues.
link_name: In contempt of the republic | By The Way| Nepali Times

status_message:
Our readers' pic this week is from Ayush Man Bajracharya of a girl filling a jerry can from a public tap in Patan Durbar Square.

The reader shared some thoughts with us: "a girl fetching water for daily consumption for her family as there's no water supply through pipeline at her home."
link_name: Daily life in Nepal through your eyes

status_message: Our reader Narayan Lamichhane posing after receiving his Nepali Times cap and two issues (#654) where his pic was published: a foreigner filming a slum area at the Bagmati riverbank while a fruit street vendor goes on to work.
How can we control corruption in Nepal?

A leopard wandered into the golf course near the airport one morning last December. It preyed on the guard dog and livestock and had the entire neighbourhood terrified.

Four months later in April, the leopard was ruthlessly beaten to death by locals of Gothatar and paraded around town like a trophy.
link_name: Preying on the predator | Nation| Nepali Times

status_message:
Check out our editorial this week on the head of the CIAA.

An important matter that has not been addressed in the past week's activism is the impact on domestic and foreign investment when you place someone of such non-credibility on the chair of the anti-graft body with the express intention of cleansing one party and hounding its political opposition. 

This will drive away anyone wanting to genuinely invest in Nepali society and will lead to capital flight – impacting employment and continuing export of youth labour to the menial Indian and overseas market.

Happy Mother's Day!

Would you like to share a message for a mother you know? Have your say in this place...

In 2010, a flash flood hit northern Afghanistan and damaged a 165-year-old public bath house, Hammam Khist-i-Kopruk. Life of an Afghan Hammam explores how the local community worked to revive an old architectural tradition to restore the building and the culture associated with it.

Written by Indian architect Tanvi Maheswari, this superbly produced book records the flood, the damage, and the painstaking restoration.
link_name: Afghan experience | Book Review| Nepali Times

status_message:
8 May is World Red Cross Day! The day celebrates the birthday of Henry Dunant, the Swiss businessman who founded the organizations that are now known as the International Red Cross and Red Crescent.

To honor the day, the Red Cross is encouraging people to donate blood. Check out this article from our archives on blood donation in Nepal.
Our readers' pic this week is from Anil K Mahaju in Eastern Terai. Anil says the photo shows "villagers enjoying mud fishing near Koshi Bridge."

What do you recommend our readers to do in Pokhara? Have your say.

status_message: Inspired by Pokhara's stunning landscape and armed with her Art School background, 22-year-old Georgina Foster from the UK started Pokhara Photography in 2012 to train young photographers in the region and encourage them to explore it as a career. Nepali Times caught up with the entrepreneur in her office at Lakeside.
link_name: Click, click | Nepali Times Buzz| Nepali Times

status_message:
Sarangkot Fordays Restaurant is a breakfast place with a difference. 

Fordays is a health drink manufacturer in Japan and this is part of its corporate social responsibility project to raise funds to run the nearby Bishnu Secondary School. Of all the great places to eat in Pokhara, at Fordays you also feel great about helping out.

It was Saturday morning of 5 May last year and many picnickers from Pokhara had come to the hot springs at Sardi Khola for a dip. Chahana Pun, 13, her family, and neighbours were also by the riverside.

Suddenly there was a roar from the north, the Seti River had turned into a brown wall of mud, boulders, and tree trunks.
link_name: The Seti settles | Nation| Nepali Times

status_message:
Nepal has a rich tradition of buildings made out of local materials such as mud, bamboo, and straw. The famous Basantapur Darbar and Singha Darbar are prime examples of mud, brick, and mortar buildings which have survived the test of time.

These traditional materials, which were cheaper, more ecological, and safer during earthquakes are giving way to concrete. As the road network spreads to rural areas, concrete is replacing traditional building materials even in the districts.
link_name: Building for tomorrow | Nation| Nepali Times

status_message:
Our editorial this week reflects on what happened at the Everest.

There are differing accounts of what happened between Camp II and III on the morning of 27 April. But both versions confirm that besides being a clash of cultures it was also a clash of egos. And it has to be said that the commercialism of Himalayan climbing has had a mercenary effect on what was once about exploration and adventure.
link_name: Clash of cultures | Editorial| Nepali Times

status_message: The incident between three climbers and Sherpas on 27 April on the Lhotse Face below Camp 3 has shaken the climbing fraternity, and divided the tourism community into distinct camps depending on whose version of events they believe more. But the bottom line is that the publicity has hurt the reputation of both sides in the mountain fight.

With modern mountaineering, the term 'sherpa' has come to mean Himalayan men working on expeditions in the Himalaya. 

But the capital 'S' Sherpas are an ethnic people whose culture is steeped in philosophical and practical traditions that helped them survive in scattered high mountain hamlets.
link_name: Speaking for the Sherpas | Nation| Nepali Times

status_message:
This edition of Nepali Times carries a special focus on Pokhara, which is emerging as the premier destination for domestic tourism. 

More and more people from Kathmandu are buying retirement homes here to escape the congestion and the chaos of the capital. 

Pokhara offers mountain views unparalleled in the world, a balmy climate, and adventure sports like paragliding, zip lining, ultra-light flights, and white water rafting. There are three museums and numerous meditation and yoga centres. Photo: Bikram Rai.
Our readers' pic this week is from Narayan Lamichhane near Balkhu. A foreigner films a slum area at the Bagmati riverbank while a fruit street vendor goes on to work.
link_name: Daily life in Nepal through your eyes

status_message: INTERNATIONAL WORKERS' DAY: A man puts up posters on the walls at Pulchok announcing May Day celebrations at Basantapur. Photo: Bikram Rai.
What's your dream job?

Nepali tweets of the week are here. Thanks to @FwDrps, @ranitakhatry, @rabirajbaral, and @MissRotasia2010.

This is the translation of one of them:
American dream: no pay raise, no promotion but work load increases daily. @FwDrps

Do you agree with the tweet? Start the debate.
link_name: Nepali tweets | Nepali Tweets| Nepali Times

status_message:
For the past month and a half, the reels of Manoj Pandit's controversial new movie, Badhshala, have shuttled back and forth between the Nepal Army, the Ministry of Defence, and the Censor Board. 

Badhshala is a flawed historical drama because it only depicts one side of the conflict and there is no doubt that the Maoist party would have reacted in exactly the same way if the story was about torture and summary executions by the Maoists.
link_name: Arms and the men | Here We Go| Nepali Times

status_message:
Many people living in Kathmandu Valley's densely populated core will not have much of a chance of survival when the next big earthquake strikes. So disaster preparedness experts are turning their attention to making sure Nepal's only international airport will be operational to fly in relief.

Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport has only one runway and geological tests have shown that parts of it are vulnerable to liquefaction damage during an earthquake.
link_name: The Kathmandu airlift | Nation| Nepali Times

status_message:
Our editorial this week reflects on how nearly a year later, we are still planning to have that election. And we are poised to repeat history because the new CA will probably get stuck on the same old issue of federalism. 

Nothing has really happened in the last 11 months to bridge the gap between the positions of those for and against single-identity federalism. From the statements of politicians and ethnic pressure groups it is clear that the elections will essentially be a referendum on federalism.

When Nepal's Maoists declared a 'people's war' in 1996, they were ridiculed at home and abroad for being on the wrong side of the history. Within a dozen years they were leading a government in Kathmandu after winning an election.

There is a myth that Nepalis are a tolerant lot with a high threshold for pain. That may be true, but they have also revolted against state oppression.
link_name: What's left of the left | By The Way| Nepali Times

status_message: Our reader Samir Pradhananga holding issue #653 with his picture of an elderly man taking food offered to a stray cow in Basantapur.

NEWLY MARRIED: A bride puts tikka on her groom's forehead during a Hindu wedding ceremony on Wednesday night in Letang. Photo: Cindrey Liu.

Have you dreamt about / do you dream about a lavish wedding ceremony?

Would you like to have a traditional wedding ceremony? Share your thoughts with us.
Our readers' pic this week by Samir Pradhananga is from an old man taking the food offered to the cow at Basantapur Durbar square. What are your thoughts on the image and the meaning of the picture?
link_name: Daily life in Nepal through your eyes

status_message:
Long before red hearts, colourful butterflies, oversized skulls, and misspelled names of loved ones became permanent accessories among Nepal's urban crowd, tattoos were an important ritual in the Newar and Tharu communities. However, it took more than two decades for the body art to gain mainstream acceptance.

Today, an increasing fascination among the young and young at heart has opened doors for tattooistas, making it a viable profession.
link_name: Get inked | Nepali Times Buzz| Nepali Times

status_message:
For the past year and a half, graphic journalist and Fulbright fellow Dan Archer travelled to Bhaktapur, Kavre, Makwanpur, Dang, and Mahendranagar gathering testimonies from trafficking survivors. 

He adapted these stories into comics and the exhibition will open this week at Image Ark Gallery. Nepali Times caught up with Archer just as he was getting ready for the opening of his exhibit.
Who is your favourite Nepali person?

A two hour bus ride from the capital past wheat and mustard fields that turn the hillsides into a mosaic of green and yellow comes Patlegaun in Kavre. At first glance, the village is like any other. But this is where 35-year-old Govinda Ghimire, owner of Patlegaun Organic Farm, is building his brand of organic vegetables and fruits which are exported as far as Australia and the UAE.

This is the story of a person who studied until grade 3, worked since he was 12 and succeeded when he was still young thanks to hard work.

Millions of terraces in Nepal that are planted with local varieties are themselves a living seed bank. This is a crucial component of global food security that has taken farmers centuries of close attention to cultivate. Should the current prohibition on the use of GM crops fall, natural cross-pollination has the potential to contaminate and effectively eradicate Nepal's biodiversity in only a matter of seasons.
link_name: Seeds of revolution | Comment| Nepali Times

status_message:
Nepal tries to make it difficult to export its exotic organic produce to the countries in the region with a customs bureaucracy, assorted airport charges, bandas (strikes) and unexpected delays. But in the end, satisfied customers in Singapore make it all worth it.

Kavre, a district east of Kathmandu, is already the centre for organic farming in Nepal, and has the potential to be branded internationally.

Internationally, social media has proven to be a fast, direct, and reliable way to reach the right people at the right time when requesting for and donating blood. And it is catching on in Nepal as well.

With nearly two million Facebook users in Nepal and Twitter picking up fast among the urban middle class with smartphones, social networking is much more accessible than it used to be.
link_name: Transfusion through social networks | Nation| Nepali Times

status_message: Our readers' pic this week is from Jamie Mitchell of a woman working with wood at the bank of Koshi River near Prakashpur.
link_name: Daily life in Nepal through your eyes

status_message:
What is the first thing that crosses your mind when you see this picture?

A father amuses his child by throwing him into the air at Patan Durbar Square on Tuesday. Photo: Cindrey Liu.

Depending on who is counting, the proportion of Nepalis who are poor is either 44 per cent, 19 per cent, or 25 per cent. But no matter which criteria is used, all indicators point to Nepal's poverty rate declining dramatically in the last 15 years.

The sharpest fall was announced earlier this month by the Oxford Poverty and Human Development Index which showed that Nepal's Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) had come down from 0.350 in 2006 to 0.217 in five years.
link_name: First the good news | Nation| Nepali Times

status_message: Kenichi Yokoyama, Country Director of the Nepal Resident Mission of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) spoke to Nepali Times this week about infrastructure bottlenecks, political fluidity affecting the investment climate and Nepal's macro economy.

The talk is all about elections under the CJ-led government in Kathmandu, but here in remote north-western Nepal people are too busy finding enough to eat to care.

Undernourished children fall prey to infections and the child and maternal mortality rates in Mugu and Bajura are more than twice the national average. These two districts are among 30 that are supposed to get food assistance from the state.
link_name: You can't eat elections | Nation| Nepali Times

status_message:
Eating and defecation. Activities so vital to our everyday lives, but which we take for granted. We don't think about them much, so we turn over the pages with coverage of charpis or chulos.

The media doesn't care much either. We would rather focus on important subjects like the debate about whether or not elections will be held in November. Yet, these are matters of life or death for most Nepalis.
link_name: Too good to be true  | Editorial| Nepali Times

Our reader Subeksha Shrestha just picked up her gifts. Check out our Readers' pic album and see how people see daily life in Nepal.

"For many of us who grew up in the Soviet Union and its satellites in Eastern Europe, Margaret Thatcher will always be a heroine", writes Yuliya Tymoshenko, twice Prime Minister of Ukraine and  political prisoner since 2011.

Nepali, Newari, Tamu Losar (Gurung), Sonam Losar (Tamang), Gyalpo Losar (Sherpa), Kirati, Islamic, and Gregorian.

status_message:
Nepali New Year 2070 is approaching soon…

What do you want to happen in Nepal in this coming year?

What do you do when there is bandh?

Men stand in the middle of Ring Road ready to stop vehicles during the national bandh called for 33 political parties including CPN (Maoist) in protest for the current government on Monday. Photo: Devyani Shiwakoti.

Urban Nepal is pre-occupied with power cuts, even though only 1.5 per cent of the country's energy need is from electricity.  

Over 80 per cent of Nepal's population, mostly women, cook on firewood, straw or dried dung. A clean and cheap new chulo could transform the lives of 20 million rural Nepalis, yet it was difficult to get anyone excited about it.
link_name: It is Rocket science | Nation| Nepali Times

status_message:
From the time Rahul Gandhi was appointed the vice-president of the Congress, the media have accused him of perpetuating dynastic rule. 

No doubt, dynasty is antithetical to democratic politics. Yet, it is also true that dynastic succession is the norm outside India as well. Its pervasiveness explains why people dismiss the hypocritical media outcry against dynastic succession to routinely vote pater familias to power.
link_name: Can't live without them | GUEST COLUMN| Nepali Times

status_message:
For decades the white washed wall linings of Kathmandu have fought a losing battle against layers and layers of political slogans and posters. 

Yuki Poudyal, the brains behind Kolor Kathmandu, along with Sattya Media Arts Collective, however, are on a mission to replace the sea of red letters and give the battered walls of this city a much needed facelift.
link_name: Koloring Kathmandu | Nepali Times Buzz| Nepali Times

status_message: The Editorial explains how the Supreme Court's stay order this week on the establishment of a Truth and Reconciliation Commission, as per the parameters promulgated by the previous government and passed as ordinance by the president, has been welcomed by families of victims as well as human rights activists.

Nepal's youth have to be an integral part of the democratic process. They have strength in numbers and can influence politics by electing accountable leaders with integrity and vision. 

The two million Nepalis who turned 18 since 2008, therefore, should be the first to get voter IDs.
link_name: Nepal's youth bulge | Here We Go| Nepali Times

status_message:
In a free-wheeling interview UCPN (Maoist) Chairman Pushpa Kamal Dahal spoke to Nepali Times and Himal Khabarpatrika on Thursday about the need for the government and Election Commission to still aim to have elections in June. Photo: Bikram Rai.

http://nepalitimes.com/article/headline/We-must,284#.UV_-tZPI12C

Rhododendron flowers + lake Rara + snow covered mountains = Perfect combination!

What are your thoughts on the picture?

status_message:
Our readers' pic this week is from Subeksha Shrestha in a very representative street in Kathmandu (do you know which road it is before reading the caption?)

Our reader shares some thoughts with us: "This is the hustle and bustle of New Road where people have forgotten how beautiful the law of nature is. Who cares for the sun? It comes and goes anyway." And she also reflects upon the busy street saying that "this same road is travelled both by multibillionaire as well as the poorest of the poor."
link_name: Daily life in Nepal through your eyes

status_message: AT THE TOP: Charles Douglas-Hamilton enjoys a flight to Mount Everest (pictured) just like his grandfather Douglas Douglas-Hamilton, first pilot to fly over the highest peak, did exactly 80 years ago, Wednesday early morning. Photo: Kunda Dixit.

Today it´s 80 years since the first ever flight over Mt Everest by two Scottish-built biplanes, and the anniversary will be marked by the grandson of one of the pilots taking a flight to Mt Everest from Kathmandu.

The Westland-Wallace planes with open cockpits took off from Purnea in Bihar and flew a roundtrip of 500 km in three hours to get to about 50 metres above the 8848m mountain. One of the planes was piloted by Colonel LVS Blacker and Douglas Douglas-Hamilton, and the other by Flight Lieutenant DF MacIntyre and Mr SR Bonnet.
link_name: Nepali Times | The Brief  » Blog Archive   » Overflying Everest 80 years on

status_message:
Former US President Jimmy Carter arrived in Burma on the first anniversary of by-elections in which Aung San Suu Kyi's NLD party won nearly all the seats it contested. Monday also saw further cautious moves towards democracy by the state with the ban lifted on private media. However, Burma's transition has been marred by religious riots and no let up in the ethnic insurgencies in the north. 

Before leaving for Burma Carter said Burma could learn from Nepal during its transition to democracy.
link_name: Nepali Times | The Brief  » Blog Archive   » To Burma from Nepal

status_message:
The Scottish exploration firm that found a billion barrels of oil in India has indicated it may give up on Nepal without a big improvement in the situation in the country. 

Nine years after Cairn was awarded licences covering a swathe of southern Nepal, the company appears to be running out of patience with a country where it has been unable to start drilling amid continuing political instability.
link_name: Cairn may give up on Nepal | Nation| Nepali Times
Short story competition » Over the top

status_message: The 10-day mountain bike race around the Annapurna Circuit is the highest and hardest in the world. Every year the competition gets stronger with more international professionals and amateurs taking part, yet every year the Nepali riders illustrate their strength at all altitudes, any terrain, and at any temperature.
link_name: Yak Attack 2013 | Nepali Times Buzz| Nepali Times

status_message:
When Prajwal Parajuly's The Gurkha's Daughter rapidly flew off the shelves (it's already in its first reprint) and garnered rave reviews everywhere, readers were left with one burning question: is it really that good? Basically, yes, yes it is. 

This is the book's review by Shreya Thapa.

Can you recommend us a book related to Nepal to review?
link_name: One of us daughters and sons  | Book Review| Nepali Times

status_message:
Our editorial this week explains how you can't figure out what is really happening in Nepal these days by listening to the politicians. Reading, watching or listening to the media isn't much help either. You find out what is happening by what a leader doesn't say. In fact, the opposite of what a politician says is usually true.

When all the main leaders show rare unity by vowing to hold elections by June, you can be pretty sure it is not going to happen.
link_name: Maybe not June | Editorial| Nepali Times

status_message:
Anurag Acharya travelled to Biratnagar and found Salim, Rahul, Dilip, and Prince celebrating Holi together. "Eid, Tihar or Holi, we are always together," Dilip said, patting Prince's back. 

The four friends represent three sections of Nepali society: Muslim, Madhesi, and Pahadi. That they were celebrating Holi together, enjoying themselves, and cementing their bonds of friendship represents hope for the nation's future.
link_name: The Holi land | By The Way| Nepali Times

status_message: Rural life seems to be a popular topic in our readers' pic photos. This week our reader Jaya Amatya features an old lady drying maize in the sun in Ghurjung, on the way to Annapurna Base Camp.

Bhanimandal, Lalitpur might not be the first place that comes to mind when you think of fine dining. But away from the city centre and tourist hubs along a quiet street, there is a restaurant that offers Western dishes in a comfortable setting.

La Soon Restaurant and Vinotheque is a lengthy name, but the joint itself is small and cosy. Located on the second floor, it's a nice place to have a long lazy meal while looking out onto the street below.

Until a decade ago joint families with grandparents, uncles, aunts, and cousins all living under the same roof was the norm in Nepal. Today's urban parents don't have that safety net and most work full-time so there is no one at home to take care of the kids. 

Pressured by an increasingly competitive education system even stay at home parents are rushing to enroll their children in good preschools.

What are your thoughts on relying children education to preschools instead of the family?
link_name: Pack their bags | Nepali Times Buzz| Nepali Times

link_name: Kathmandu's best kept secret. Shhh. | Nation| Nepali Times

status_message:
Our Editorial this week explains how the ultimate test for the Chairman of the Interim Election Council of Ministers Khil Raj Regmi and his new 11-member cabinet of ex-bureaucrats will be whether or not they can hold elections in November or whenever.

Given the mess that he inherited, Regmi has an unenviable task in the months ahead. There is a fuel and electricity crisis, the lawlessness on the streets borders on anarchy, fringe parties are on a warpath, and he has to keep the Big Four at arms length if he is to be successful.

After nine months of to-ing and fro-ing over reinstatement of the dissolved Constituent Assembly, then a year of haggling over who should lead an elections government, Nepal will hold another CA elections later this year. 

For an electorate that has been denied franchise for so long, it doesn't seem to matter that no dates have been announced yet.
link_name: Free of fear | By The Way| Nepali Times

status_message: After decades of corrupt, incompetent and irresponsible mis-rule by politicians of all stated ideological hues, the Chief Justice-led election government is the best thing to have happened to the people of Nepal, writes the guest columnist Bihari Krishna Shrestha.
link_name: Unfree and unfair? | GUEST COLUMN| Nepali Times

status_message:
The 18-day classic around the Annapurna massif is fading into history. Trekkers still lug their packs over the 5400m Thorung-La, but their numbers are much diminished. 

Tourism entrepreneurs are no longer able to ignore the impact of the ragged scratch of a road the Nepal Army has blasted up on either side of the horseshoe circuit. With other trails opening up across the country (notably, the Manaslu Circuit next door), there's no doubt the region's crown jewel of a trek has lost its lustre.
link_name: Off the road | Nepali Times Buzz| Nepali Times

status_message:
Let's start the week with some political-philosophical reflections by Ass:
"Now we know why BRB was in such a tearing hurry to step down. He just couldn't wait to get rid of that damn Mustang Max. No sooner had he resigned, he drove out of Shit All Niwas to Sanepa in a Scorpio and tweeted en route: "I'm a free citizen!" 

Which begs the question: he wasn't free as PM? Who took away his freedom? A miniature stuffed donkey to the first 10 correct answers." 

Any idea?
link_name: Chief Justice + Prime Minister = Chief Minister  | Backside| Nepali Times

@dhwoje, @Rubz_runa, @pkrkaru, and @Pokharelbp.

status_message:
In November 2012 in the US- Mexico border at Texas, the Border Patrol detained a Nepali man who was trying to get into the country illegally. This would have been just another case of illegal entry if the detainee had not been coughing constantly. 

The police made him undergo a health examination which showed he had tuberculosis (TB), not the regular, drug-sensitive TB, but the resistant kind.
link_name: Travelling TB | Nepali Times Buzz| Nepali Times

status_message:
Debate about the efficacy of foreign aid in Nepal is as old as foreign aid itself.

Lately, this debate has become more complicated because of the assertiveness shown by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the NPC, and the Finance Ministry about where aid should go and a new scrutiny of NGOs and INGOs which operate here.

What are your thoughts on the debate?
link_name: Rules of engagement | Nation| Nepali Times

status_message:
Our editorial this week reflects on how nation states come with user manuals, they are called constitutions. It is a trouble-shooting guide to tell us what to do when things go awry.

Nepal came with a fairly complete user manual in 1990, but since the politicians never read it, they deemed it necessary to write a new one.
link_name: Let's face it | Editorial| Nepali Times

status_message: YES WE CAN: Leaders of the four major parties have agreed on making amendments to the constitution in order to swear in Chief Justice Khil Raj Regmi to lead the electoral government.

Russian ambassador to Nepal Sergey Vasilievich Velichkin has been in the country since 2010, holds a PhD in Indology, and speaks Urdu and Bengali. He spoke to Nepali Times last week about the history of Russia-Nepal relations, the current political deadlock, and even about how road-widening will affect his embassy.
link_name: "Make the rules and stick to them" | Nation| Nepali Times

status_message:
The Far Western districts of Nepal have a reputation for being neglected and more under-developed than the rest of the country. But in the past 15 years, they have taken great strides in transportation, infrastructure and child and maternal survival.

Check out this photo report by Kunda Dixit in Doti.
link_name: My City | Photo blog from Nepali Times  » Blog Archive   » Not-so-far West

status_message:
We invite our readers to send us pictures of daily life in Nepal with a brief description (location, subject, and thoughts on the image). We will upload them onto our Facebook page and Twitter, and publish the best ones on our Happenings section. Pictures should be in hi-res (300dpi), horizontal, full colour, unedited, and maximum 2MB. E-mail to Juanita@nepalitimes.com

The selected readers' pic receives a Nepali Times cap and two courtesy copies of the issue where the picture has been published.

Our readers' pic this week is an aerial view of Kathmandu valley and is taken by Sathaporn Kamkong. Our reader says that it's amazing how they're building brick factories one after another in Bhaktapur. "They are like mushrooms popping up from the ground. I always wondered how many bricks they have been making over the years: millions!
link_name: Daily life in Nepal through your eyes

status_message:
A busy alley in Khichapokhari, in the heart of Kathmandu's main business district, is abuzz with shoppers. The one stop solution for retail therapy recently had a kinky addition: Khichapokhari is now home to two registered sex toy shops.

Alongside clothing stores, there's a shop where shelves are laden with bright coloured toys and devices that hint at unimaginable pleasure.

What do you think of sex shops in Kathmandu?
link_name: Think in kink | Nepali Times Buzz| Nepali Times

status_message:
Check out the food review of a restaurant in Lumbini.

If you're looking to sample some southern delights during your stay at Lumbini, you will be sorely disappointed because most restaurants here offer the usual Nepali/Indian/Chinese/Continental muddle like Thamel.

We picked 3 Fox Restaurant because it had been highly recommended by travellers on the web. The place is decent with very basic décor.

The Editorial this week reflects on whatever the outcome of the Supreme Court verdict on the writ petition challenging the legality of the UCPN(M) proposal to make Chief Justice Khil Raj Regmi the head of an election government, the question is not 'if' there will be elections, but 'when'.

The big question: when do you think there will be elections?

Nepal's inability to sign the 1951 Refugee Convention and blatant violation of customary international laws in the treatment of refugees fly in the face of the Foreign Minister who makes lofty claims about defending national interests.

We don't just have the right but an obligation to protest against government policies that have turned us into an international pariah.
link_name: Foreign domestic policy | By The Way| Nepali Times

status_message:
On occasion of Women's day, Deepti Gurung our guest columnist writes about how Nepali women are discriminated against at all levels, but they face further ostracisation on the issue of citizenship.

She explains her situation as a divorced mother whose children don't have Nepali citizenship even if she's Nepali.

What are your thoughts on Nepali patriarchal society that doesn't allow citizenship through the mother?
link_name: Nepal's gender apartheid | GUEST COLUMN| Nepali Times

status_message:
The readers' pic this week is from Mangal Daydreamer and it was taken in Mangal Bazar, Lalitpur. The picture shows day labourers waiting for potential clients at the entrance of Patan Durbar Square. 
Our reader has shared some thoughts with us: "People often migrate from the villages to the city in search of better future and end up working for a minimal income all their life as these labours. Not only do they not have a proper reliable income to secure their future, they are often humiliated and yelled at by the people who hire them."
link_name: Daily life in Nepal through your eyes

status_message:
The God gives up at Teaching Hospital. 
Dr. Bhagwan Koirala resigns from Teaching.
link_name: Nepali Times | The Brief  » Blog Archive   » Politics kill

status_message:
Don't miss what Ass has to say this week:
"Under a new get-tough policy Police HQ has sent out an order for a nationwide crackdown on people of the male persuasion wearing pony tails and ear-rings. Wimmin with long hair and nose rings, however, are for now exempted from this clampdown on anti-socialist elements." 

"So folks, if you need a free haircut contact the police hotline on 100. And we hear from unusually reliable sources that the next target of the police vigilance squad will be hardcore criminals who flout the law by piercing belly buttons, wearing tattoos on their butts, and dyeing their hair with henna." Cartoon by Diwakar Chhetri.

After a decade of struggle and perseverance, the Nepal National Mountain Guide Association has finally been certified by the International Federation of Mountain Guide Associations (IFMGA).

What makes this award special is that Nepal is the only other country in Asia besides Japan to be recognised by the IFMGA and it means our mountaineering guides are now part of an elite rank and can display skills and expertise from the Alps to the Andes and the Himalaya.
link_name: Because they are there | Nation| Nepali Times

status_message:
It's 9AM in Ratna Park. Street vendors have neatly laid out packets of cigarettes, chewing tobacco, and beetle nuts on the sidewalk. A group of men puffs away, discussing politics. At the microbus stand, drivers gesture to passengers with one hand and drag on a cigarette with the other.

The government finally banned smoking in public in August last year. But despite the ban people are still smoking in public places.
link_name: Ashes to ashes | Nation| Nepali Times

status_message:
The accelerated melting of the Himalaya has often been blamed on the greenhouse effect caused by the historical emissions of carbon dioxide by rich countries. And this has been used as an excuse by developing countries to blame the west and do nothing to control their own emissions.

Read this article by Bhrikuti Rai about why they can't do that any longer.
link_name: Back to black | Nation| Nepali Times

status_message:
Our editorial this week explains how the country has been flying on autopilot, without a constitution, without parliament, without budgets, without accountability, with no hope for local and general elections. 

The economy was a wreck, a kleptocratic coalition had surpassed all past records for plunder, and development had come to a standstill. When all other options failed, the idea of the chief justice to lead an election government became the only one that worked.
link_name: Stability at what cost? | Editorial| Nepali Times

status_message:

What's the buzz?

The readers' pic this week is at a market in Lukla. Our reader Tone Drabløs was stuck for five days in Lukla because a heavy fog prevented aircrafts from landing and taking off. 
Far from being a problem, she says it gave her the opportunity to explore the city and its surroundings for a couple of days. "Some of my companion travellers almost went nuts from waiting, but for me, it was five 'bonus days'", she explains.
link_name: Daily life in Nepal through your eyes

Buzz. 
Buzz?
What's the buzz?

This is the story of Mahabir Pun who won the Ramon Magsaysay Award in 2007 for his project to bring wireless Internet to rural Nepal, he found out last week that the Internet was also a great way to remotely get through to the PM.

Pun had met PM Bhattarai a year ago to discuss his pet idea to set up a National Innovation Centre to generate jobs so Nepalis don't have to migrate abroad for work. Bhattarai said it was a great idea and instructed his office to implement it.

As expected, nothing happened, until last week...
link_name: Innovating a new Nepal | Nation| Nepali Times

status_message:
As roads snake up to Manang and even Mustang is connected to the highway grid, trekkers are looking for regions untouched by the internal combustion engine. Because of its proximity to Kathmandu, its mountain wilderness and the rich Tibetan culture, the attraction of the Manaslu Circuit is spreading by word of mouth.

Do you have a favourite trekking in Nepal you'd like to recommend?
link_name: In the Mountain of the Soul | Life Times| Nepali Times

status_message:
When the Malaysian government increased the minimum wage for domestic and foreign workers to at least Rs 25,172 last month, Nepalis there were overjoyed. 

But what the Malaysian government gave with one hand, it was pressured to take with the other. It announced the minimum wage increase and a month later, workers were required to pay a housing and food levy to employers after it came under pressure from factory owners.
link_name: No big deal | Nation| Nepali Times

status_message: We hear a buzz, do you?

Our Editorial this week reflects on how the art of compromise is based on the premise that both sides in an argument give in a little. Unfortunately, politics in Nepal has become a zero sum game where both sides want all or nothing. Every concession is seen as a sign of weakness. Our so-called leaders don't just want to be top dog, they want to be the only dog.

What are your thoughts on the Editorial?
link_name: Electing to go for elections | Editorial| Nepali Times

status_message:
Today is International Mother language Day!

The date represents the day in 1952 when students demonstrating for recognition of their language, Bangla, as one of the two national languages of the then Pakistan, were shot and killed by police in Dhaka, the capital of what is now Bangladesh.

Read this article from our archives on the importance to document Nepal's increasingly endangered linguistic diversity 

Languages are the most powerful instruments of preserving and developing our tangible and intangible heritage, says the UN. Do you agree with the statement?
Mahabir Pun needs help to scale up his award-winning work in a remote Kaski village to the national level.. Read more

status_message: Long wait: Debi Sunuwar at Baluwatar on Saturday demanding justice for her daughter Maina Sunuwar who was allegedly tortured and killed by Nepal Army officers in 2004
Ugly Confrontation: Occupy Baluwatar going strong on day 52

Our columnist Anurag Acharya writes, "history has always privileged the powerful, but it has also given the oppressed the right to protest. Nepal's political future hangs uncertainly waiting for a resolution between the two. When that happens, reconciliation will take care of itself."  

http://nepalitimes.com/regular-columns/by-the-way/Reconciliation-without-resolution,47#.UR4s2mc9Lqw

The Editorial this week reflects upon Nepal's violent conflict and how it ended in 2006 with a lot of loose ends. 

"As peace studies expert Johan Galtung reminded an audience in Kathmandu, although the violence stopped seven years ago, the conflict didn't. Unless the unresolved conflicts that led to violence are addressed, the war could reignite", says the Editorial.

Do you agree with the concept that unresolved conflicts fuel violence?

http://nepalitimes.com/article/editorial/Lost-in-transition,164#.UR4p2mc9Lqw

One hundred Tibetan monks and nuns have set themselves on fire in protest against the Chinese presence in Tibet
(Update)
link_name: Self-immolation moves to Nepal |  Nepali Times

status_message: Our readers' pic this week is of an old lady sitting by the window, taken by Reshav Malla. Here is the story behind the photo: "I was strolling around and admiring the beauty of the architecture of old buildings in Patan Durbar Square when suddenly I saw her. I'm studying abroad right now and this picture reminds me of my mother country."
link_name: Daily life in Nepal through your eyes

status_message:
SPREADING KNOWLEDGE: Professor Johan Galtung, founder of Peace Research Institute in Oslo, answers questions after his talk on Peace Journalism at Patan Dhoka on Tuesday. Photo: Cindrey Liu.

Among other things he says:
Conflict in Nepal didn't stop in 2006, what stopped was violence.
Unresolved conflicts fuels violence.
If you want peace give up inequality.
Before reconciliation it's necessary a solution.

This interview with Professor Galtung, from our archives, is about the importance of federalism in Nepal and how the new constitution should be shaped:
http://nepalitimes.com/news.php?id=19705#.URsDzqWTh2A

Don't miss this article on how in the last 20 years social research in Nepal has taken a back seat, making it difficult to understand Nepali society's changing dynamics. 

Although there are about 200 private research firms across the country, increasing political interference and lack of neutrality worries many.

Our editorial reflects on Bhattarai's time in power.
"It should by now be clear to everyone, including the internationals, that the Maoist revolution was never about empowering the oppressed, about inclusion or democracy. They say they are a 'civilian party', but have simultaneously announced they can resort to violence if they aren't allowed to reach their goals. In Hetauda the party also unveiled a 'production' ideology patterned after Mao's disastrous Great Leap Forward. 

They have us all fooled: it was always about absolute power."

Check out this article by Sulaiman Daud about the challenges people with disabilities need to face in the streets of Kathmandu. 

He tells the story of Bal Krishnan who navigates through chaotic roads every day from his home in Jawalakhel to his work and back. But afflicted with polio from an early age, he cannot walk and has to make this journey on a wheelchair.
link_name: No right of passage |  Nepali Times

status_message: Sneak peek at tomorrow's issue: Interview with Everest Bank's CEO about the difficulties in keeping tabs on remittances from India, Nepal's inability to boost capital formation and why agriculture in Nepal needs a boost.

On Monday representatives from 19 Asian countries, including Nepal's Minister for Science, Technology and Environment Keshab Man Shakya, gathered in Bangkok for a two day meeting to explore ways to reduce the impacts of short-lived climate pollutants (SLCPs) like  methane, ozone and hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), and black carbon (soot).
link_name: Nepali Times | The Brief  » Blog Archive   » Clean sweep

status_message:
As the first light of dawn brightens the streets of Rangoon, news vendors are busy distributing the day's magazines and journals. With Burma freeing up its press and the country taking faltering steps towards democracy, circulation is booming.

But there is one magazine missing this morning: Nhyot, Burma's first sex magazine.
link_name: Too hot to handle |  Nepali Times

status_message: Belgian photographer Frédéric Lecloux explains why he often comes back to Nepal: "Nothing offends me: death, violence, fever, the air drizzling with dust and heavy metals, the overload of the space. I am in the right place. A place that is searching for balance, a balance between order and disorder, between fiction and reality. This is the Nepal I capture on my lens and where I begin to find my answer to "why Nepal?"

The death of Catherine "Kitty" Houghton has shocked Nepal's growing community of women pilots who were inspired by her to set up the Nepal Section of the Ninety-Nines.

Kitty spoke fluent Nepali and remained connected to Nepal after retirement from the US Foreign Service. She visited the country several times to support educational and other initiatives in Dhankuta, and to interact with and encourage Nepali women pilots.

I AM LEGEND: UCPN(M) Chairman Pushpa Kamal Dahal greets cadre at the party's seventh general convention in Hetauda on Saturday afternoon. This is the first convention of its kind in more than 20 years. (PIC: BIKRAM RAI)

The editorial reflects on Nepal's linguistic diversity, how it mirrors the country's ecological diversity and is an important identity marker. Language is an emotive issue, and if not treated adequately can lay the seeds of future conflict, especially when leaders cannot resist the temptation to make populist capital out of it at election time.

Do you agree with the editorial?
BURGLAR PROOF: A welder works late into the evening as he fixes a metal fence at a house near Gyaneswor on Wednesday. Photo: Sunir Pandey.

Our reader's pic this week is from Jay Poudyal who took this picture of a chok in Khokana, which is also a premise of a temple where people and neighbours gather. These are the thoughts on the photo: "What I saw was a glimpse of medieval Nepal, people basking in the sun, close communal bond and farmers who still rely on traditional but functional farming methods and oil extraction." (Note of the editor: Khokana is in Lalitpur, south of Kathmandu)
link_name: Daily life in Nepal through your eyes

We created this space for comments but if you want to tell us in private what you think, please send an email to juanita@nepalitimes.com

1. Are there proper conditions for people with disabilities in Kathmandu? 
2. (If yes) Have conditions improved over the last few years?
3. What can be done to help disabled people in Kathmandu?

Don't miss this film review on Lincoln by Sophia Pande. 

Lincoln is Steven Spielberg's masterpiece, with a little help from Daniel Day-Lewis. In many ways, this latest profound and layered film is Spielberg's most thoughtful and adult film to date.

Check out this article on how the longer this endless transitional period drags on, the more painful it is for the families of victims of the conflict. The past month, especially, has proven beyond doubt that truth and justice are not priorities for this government.
link_name: Voice of the victims |  Nepali Times

status_message:
Started by Prem Bohara and Megha Pradhananga Malla in 2012, Shiksha Nepal believes that reading stories and poetry in Nepali and English will help children improve their comprehension, expose them to diverse cultures and lifestyles, and make them well-rounded citizens.

What are your thoughts on reading stories helps children make them well-rounded citizens? Have your say.

The editorial this week explains how Nepal's present rulers are pushing the country into a state of statelessness so systematically that it almost seems deliberate. 

And it has some examples: It is now coming up to nine months that a caretaker government is being led by a lameduck prime minister. We haven't had a parliament since May, and no sign that there will be elections any time soon. The Supreme Court is being depleted of justices.

Read what else the editorial has to say about the political status of the country these days.

Last week, the Yale Himalaya Initiative and the Nepali Association of Yale Affiliates (NAYA) hosted the screening of new wave Nepali film 'Highway' and a discussion with the director, Deepak Rauniyar.

Read Highway's review by Mark Turin and tell us what you think about a Nepali film screening in the USA: http://nepalitimes.com/article/review/Highway-in-America,117#.UQJUor-Th2A .

Damakant Jayshi, our columnist, writes about PM in power. He wonders what gives Bhattarai the confidence to continue. 

"He failed to hold elections in November, he's cashed in on the lack of foresight of the NC and UML since he knew they would not accept an election government led by him. And he is now openly obstructing justice over conflict-era abuses."

Do you agree with his statement?

status_message: CLOSER LOOK: A visitor inspects a painting on Monday at the the 'Emergence of Nepali Modern Art: 1960-80' exhibit. The exhibition runs until 31 January at Park Gallery in Pulchok. (Pic:  Cindrey Liu)

Kesar Lall (Shrestha) was one of Nepal's best-known folklorists and most widely published writers. He published over 50 books of stories and translations alongside significant collections of poetry and journalism in Nepali and Newari as well as in English. Kesar Lall passed away last month at the age of 85. 

Read the excerpts from a long interview with Kesar Lall conducted by Mark Turin in Kathmandu, 10 years ago.

Our editorial this week reflects on how 'protecting the peace process' has become a euphemism for both the Maoists and the security forces to push a blanket pardon for all those involved in war crimes.

Do you agree with the editorial?

Nepal gears up to mark another anniversary of the devastating 8.4 magnitude earthquake that struck Kathmandu on 15 January 1934. The public is aware of what a tremor can do, but few are planning for the aftermath of a disaster. 

However, awareness generation, donor pressure, and scare tactics seem to be finally shaking up the government. 

What do you think about earthquake awareness and preparedness?

Our columnist Puja Tandon says that Nepal needs a definitive economic agenda in this coming year and cannot afford to let politics overrule the economy. 

"However, with elections announced for in April, it is likely that the parties will waste the first quarter of 2013 trying to build consensus and the economy will be forced to take a back seat once again", she concludes.

What are your thought?
link_name: Investing in the future -  Nepali  Times

status_message:
When the Nepal Investment Year was announced last year, the Nepalese Chambers of Commerce and Industries announced that if our economy was to grow by 8 percent a year, up to 40 percent of the GDP must be invested into businesses. This meant that the country needed to attract foreign direct investment (FDI) from abroad. 

One year on, there has hardly been any new FDI, and even the existing investors are on the verge of packing up to leave. Don't miss this article by Sunir Pandey on crisis that risk investment in Nepal.
link_name: Nepal's fiscal cliff in 2013 -  Nepali  Times

status_message:
Don't miss the film review of The Hobbit: An unexpected journey.

What are your thoughts of this kind of films showing in Kathmandu?
link_name: The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey  -  Nepali  Times

status_message:
Our columnist Ajaz Ashraf writes about how in hierarchical societies people empathise with the suffering of those who share their circumstances. That is the case of the massive reaction towards the recent rape of the student in Delhi and the little attention other cases attracted. 

"It is possible those protesting on the streets of Delhi can understand through their own experience the pain and anger of the marginalised. Hopefully, they'd learn that their redemption lies in smashing the hierarchy of sorrow", he argues
link_name: The privilege of grief         -  Nepali  Times

status_message:
Check out Ass' column this week.

"On a recent flight to Malaysia, Nepali workers suddenly all burst out laughing when the in-flight announcement ended with 'Terima Khasi', which loosely translated means 'your mother is a goat', or words to that effect. There was even louder and naughtier merriment when the meal trays were handed out, and the Nepalis on board were amused at the Malay words on the sugar sachets that read 'GulaPutih'", he says.
link_name: The asstrologer's prognosis for 2013 -  Nepali  Times

status_message:
In his column, Anurag Acharya reflects upon what we did and we didn't do during this year. He argues that what we did not do in 2012 will come back to haunt us in 2013.

"The Prime Minister promised new elections by 22 November. That deadline came and went, and the Prime Minister has refused steadfastly to step down. We are going through the umpteenth presidential ultimatum to the political parties to come up with a formula to set up a new government to oversee elections. If they can't meet that deadline by next week, which seems likely, elections in May 2013 are impossible."

Do you agree with his statement?

Our editorial this week is a description of what 2012 has been: 

"The past year was one of missed opportunities, squandered mandates, wasted prospects. It was marred by political brinkmanship, blackmail and reckless identity politics (...) It is difficult to imagine that the Nepali state can do any worse in 2013, but it looks like we are headed for another 365 days of the same", it says. 

What's your year's review?

This article is about a young Nepali woman returning from Saudi Arabia who is robbed by immigration officials and raped by a policeman.

She told Nepali Times her story.

PERFECT BALANCE: A man peacefully sails his boat down the Rapti River in Chitwan, on Tuesday. Photo: Bikram Rai

This story from Nagarik News tells the journey of a 32 year-old Nepali who does whatever it takes to reach the US. 

It means, after flying to Doha, he travelled overland from Sao Paulo to Guatemala City via Bolivia, Peru, Ecuador, Colombia, Panama, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, El Salvador and Honduras. He's still in Guatemala, but four other friends from his village in Tanahu have already entered the US.

A journey that's taken him six months and Rs 500,000 so far and no guarantee he'd eventually reach the US.

What do you think about the story? Share your thoughts with us.
link_name: Nepali Times | The Brief  » Blog Archive   » El Norte

status_message:
This column by Ajaz Ashraf explains how the debate over wether Sachin Tendulkar should retire is rooted in a feudal mind-set.

"The irritatingly passionate debate whether Tendulkar should retire from international cricket is closely linked to the saga of how Indians turned him into a national icon. Deification is embedded deep into the collective South Asian psyche." 

"(…) From gods we ultimately become a tad alienated as our supplications do not lead to divine intercession, prompting some of us to turn away from them".

Do you think, Nepalis also tend to over-praise people and then turn away from them? Have your say.

This article on how patriarchal practices affect women highlights the discrimination faced by some of them at the hands of their own community. 

"Discrimination has its roots in their alienation from social, economic and political life. The victims of rape, torture and other forms of domestic violence are mostly poorer, illiterate women. Perpetrators of the violence walk free because they enjoy political patronage", writes Anurag Achararya.
link_name: Patriarchy in the political hierarchy     -  Nepali  Times

status_message:
Let's start the week with Ass' reflection:

"So it looks like Dhrube the rogue elephant has been machine gunned to death in Chitwan. Interesting that the citizens of Madi closed down Chitwan demanding that Dhrube be executed for killing two people, when the human killers of 36 bus passengers in 2005 are roaming free in the home of the brave."

Any other thoughts for the week?
link_name: Prime Minister eats a rat -  Nepali  Times

Directed by Ang Lee (Brokeback Mountain) the film is the adaptation of the fantasy adventure homonymous novel by Yann Martel.

status_message:
Check out this article on sexual violence against women in the eastern Tarai districts that has reached epidemic levels. The reason is that perpetrators don't just go free, but are often rewarded for their crime. 

Most incidents go unreported in the media, and rape for ransom has become a thriving business because of impunity. Many of the victims are minors violated by neighbours, teachers and relatives, but are forced into a settlement.

And many victims fear to report the crime.
Did you know that Nepal has a local chocolate factory? It's in Kathmandu and it all started as a hobby, but with time it grew into a business that is well known among locals and expats.
link_name: Sristi and her chocolate factory -  Nepali  Times

status_message:
Christmas is around the corner and bakeries in Kathmandu are working hard to offer a wide range of delicacies to their clients. They have given yet another yummy reason to rejoice!

How do you see this business oportunity in a country that traditionally doesn't celebrate Christmas?
link_name: Let them all eat cake -  Nepali  Times

status_message:
The editorial this week reflects on our children and the way they are affected by crimes against humanity. They are not just dying, they are being killed by state neglect, bureaucratic apathy, corruption and bad governance. 

What are your thoughts on how our actions have an effect on our children?

What's your view on Nelson Mandela's words: "There can be no keener revelation of a society's soul than the way in which it treats its children."

Read this article about the peace process in Colombia, a Latin American country, and how after decades of war, peace may be finally breaking out. 
What can other countries learn from Nepali's peace process with the Maoists?
Don't miss this column by Juanita Malagon on how the peace process with the FARC guerrilla might take Colombia through the same challenges Nepal has already experienced.

status_message:
Our columnist Puja Tandon asks a question to make us think: "Why do Nepali women shy away from senior management positions both in the public and private sector?"

She has some reflections to add to the debate.
- "Does our traditional education system train them to undervalue their competence? 
- Or are women so disillusioned with aggressive corporate competition that they have no aspirations to be a part of the C-suite? 
- Or are there socio-cultural barriers and invisible biases at play?"

What is your opinion?

The message of the article by David H Shinn is simple and clear: until we stop tolerating intolerance, the abuse of minorities and the reactions to it will not end.

What are your thoughts on the statement?

Check out this article on the presence of Nepali radio stations on the internet. Read how our nationals studying or working abroad are establishing Nepal's presence on the global airwaves by providing news, information, and entertainment to the diaspora community in their mother tongue.

There are now six stations in the US and Australia, and a couple in South Korea.

Do you use this service? Which stations do you tune?

Ass has been busy writing a list of ten possible directions Nepal could take in 2013. Here we give you only five:

1. BRB continues as PM for life 
2. President extends deadline for formation of consensus govt till December 31, 2022
3. PKD outfoxes BRB and makes himself PM 
4. Prez appoints an Ass as prime minister 
5. The world is ending next week, so who gives a fig?

Would you add more options?

Darjeeling and Ilam are not much different in terms of geography: beautiful tea gardens and panoramic views of the Kanchenjunga range. However, it takes a quick three hour drive into the Indian town to realise how much of Ilam's potential is going to waste especially in tourism. 

What happens in Illam?
link_name: The town less travelled -  Nepali  Times

Read this piece by Anurag Acharya. He writes that in the last two decades, the Nepali media has greater freedom than those in other South Asian countries. However, it still faces threats to freedom from over-commercialisation, politicisation, state pressure, and self-censorship.
 
He concludes that, "when civil society itself is polarised, it is unrealistic to expect the media to behave differently."
 
For you, media is a reflection of society and vice versa?

Astronaut Ron Garan tweeted a photo of Mount Everest from the space, on Sunday. He wrote: "I never got a good shot of Mount Everest" and the tweet went viral. The debate started in Nepal and according to some mountains' experts Mount Everest is not pictured. 
The debate is still on. 
And the question that remains is, where on Earth is this?
We'd like to know your thoughts.

The jury said "The film is extremely subtle in the way it deals with the subject, letting us into the lives of two different cultures caught in a time warp from two century's ago".

Read the article about the documentary published in NT one month ago.

Ravi Shankar, the sitar player, died yesterday in California, US. He was 92 years old and one of the most representative of South Asian music. He also played with The Beatles in the 1960s, and was the father of singer Nora Jones. 

Watch this video from Ravi's performance at Woodstock.

The controversial Narendra Modi, current chief minister of the Indian state of Gujarat, runs for elections.

More than half of Nepal's 26 million strong population are economically active, in other words between the ages of 15 and 64. About 500,000 young adults enter the job market annually, but the market is able to absorb only ten per cent. The remaining, join the three million Nepalis working abroad in Asia, US, and Europe.

Are we 'Ad portas' of  a brain drain?

Let's start the week with a picture from our reader Desiree Francis. A young student learning at a Thangka art institute, works on her piece of art depicting a Buddhist deity scene, in Thamel. This Nepali art began in 11 century AD when Buddhists and Hindus began to make illustration of the deities and natural scenes. Our reader says, "other than the Everest, this form of art is one of the unique things about Nepal".
link_name: Daily life in Nepal through your eyes

Nepal belongs to the top ten emotionless countries in the world. Only 38% report feeling any kind of emotion (either positive or negative). On the other hand, Philippines are the most emotional. Other emotionless countries are Madagascar, Russia and Lithuania.

World AIDS Day is celebrated today
 
The 2011 estimated HIV infection in Nepal stands at around 55.000. In 2009 it was about 65.000 and in 2007 around 69.000.
 
In Nepal, about 12% of people living with HIV reported losing a job or income on the basis of their HIV status, according to UNAIDS report 2012.
 
Read the complete report here: http://www.unaids.org/en/resources/campaigns/20121120_globalreport2012/globalreport/

Twenty years ago it was the day on which emerged in the Indian society a new break, writes our columnist Ajaz Ashraf. It was the time the word 'they' acquired another meaning. 

"Who constituted 'they' and who 'we'? Religion was not always the factor determining membership to either of the two categories. You were 'they' or 'we' depending on your position on Babri Masjid mosque in Ayodhya, whether you believed its destruction was a wedge driven into the very heart of India or, alternatively, an expression of Hindu resurgence, necessary as well as inevitable", he concludes.

"I met a boy who used to look after the horses. As it was a summer day, he was tired on the way and was sitting on a wooden plank watching the trekkers passing by. He had his own story, he too had a dream and he too wanted to study (as me) but the circumstances and the poverty forced him to give up on his dream and rather earn some money for his family", the reader says. status_message: STRENGTH IN NUMBERS: Neighbours and passer-bys help to untangle the wires of the traffic pole before its relocation in the same street at Kumaripati road, on Tuesday afternoon. Photo: Skye McParland

Some quick facts about Nepal revealed by the Final Population and Housing Census 2011, released by CBS:

- Country's population has increased by 3.3 million in ten years. We are now 26,494,504 people.
- Males account for 48.50 per cent of the population while 51.50 per cent are females.
- The highest population density is in Kathmandu district (4,416 persons per square km) and lowest in Manang district (3 persons per square km).
- There are 125 ethnic groups and 123 languages spoken as mother tongue. Nepali is spoken as mother tongue by 44.6 percent (even though it's the official language).
- Overall literacy rate is 65.9 per cent. Male literacy rate is 75.1 per cent compared to 57.4 per cent of female literacy rate.

How are we doing according to these facts? We'd like to know your opinion.
link_name: Nepali Times | The Brief  » Blog Archive   » Twenty six million strong

status_message:
Society is still talking about Maoist chairman's slap and Ass as member of our society has wise words and even some tips to avoid injury. 

"Now that all three leaders of the three main parties have been slapped, Madhesi leaders must be wondering who among them is next", he says and we give you here one of his tips, "to meet cadre only through Facebook, not face-to-face."
link_name: Plutocracy of the Red Elite -  Nepali  Times

status_message:
Read this story on how a community didn't wait anymore for government promises and came together to bring power to their town. 

Chhisti is one of the few remote villages in Nepal that is connected to the national electricity grid, and what makes it even more unique is that power distribution is efficiently and honestly managed by the local community.

Tritha B Shrestha writes that the biodiversity of the Chure forests is much greater than other parts of Nepal, and as a consequence it is under severe threat. 

He highlights that, "the politicians in Kathmandu with their power-addled brains have no time to think about this frightening destruction that will have far-reaching impact on the economy, livelihood, and future existence of our nation".
link_name: Help save the Chure Hills -  Nepali  Times

status_message:
Maureen Bisilliat is 82 years old and she came all the way from Brazil to Nepal to show her photos in Kathmandu International Art Festival. She has the energy of a teenager and the curiosity of a child. Elements that have helped her in her career as a photographer, she says. 

What do you think of a 82 year-old being active and still working?

Our editorial this week says: "The NC and UML are badly advised if they think the people will spontaneously pour out into the streets to oust Bhattarai. They want our bickering politicos to sort out their quarrels, agree on an all-party election government, and hold polls in six months time and let the chips fall where they may. Is that too much to ask?"

What could politicians expect this time from the people?

The only medical school in Nepal designed to train doctors to serve in rural areas has been paralysed by the political appointment of a new chief. As a consequence, staff at the Patan Academy of Health Sciences (PAHS) have partially shut down the hospital in protest.

We'd like to ask you: What do you think about politics mixing with health issues?

Universities and medical institutions in the country reflect the symptoms of an ailing state: deteriorating law and order, impunity, and political interference. 

Our columnist Anurag Acharya says, "One of the hallmarks of Nepal's prolonged transition is that it has led to a crisis of legitimacy at all levels".
PEACEFUL ENVIRONMENT: Our reader David Singh sent us this picture taken in a quiet day far from busy town in Pokhara. "Boats scatter around on the bank of Fewa lake!!!", he says.
link_name: Daily life in Nepal through your eyes

status_message: President's political advisor Rajendra Dahal has confirmed that the President has now approved the budget.

status_message: Don't miss this article on how setting their bodies on fire, Tibetan protesters are in reality cremating themselves and mocking their tormentors according to our columnist Ajaz Ashraf.

Medicine is a social service, not a way to get rich quick, says a faculty at Patan Academy of Health Sciences which has produced doctors and health professionals who turn down 'attractive' salaries in private clinics of Kathmandu to serve in Nepal's rural outback.

Check out this article on Kesang Tseten's latest film 'The flags of their fathers', selected for IFDA in Amsterdam. The documentary shows the process of Gurkha enrolment.
 
Gurkha recruitment provokes divided opinion in Nepal. Some say dying for another country is shameful while others believe recruitment in the British Army is a chance to uphold the Gurkha reputation as brave, loyal, and skilful soldiers.

What is your side?

status_message:
A year after declaring investment a priority, lack of progress in governance and transparency are keeping investors away from Nepal. 

Our columnist Pooja Tandon writes, "it isn't fair to blame just the government for not being able to provide a conducive investment climate. Its efforts have been defeated repeatedly by the monopolistic attitude of the private sector."

Kathmandu Art Festival is coming from the 25 November to 21 December. We will see top international and local artists collaborating on this year's theme of 'Earth-Body-Mind' and transcending cultural boundaries.

Is the city prepared to host artists from 31 countries?
DIRTY AIR: View of Kathmandu Valley on Saturday morning clearly showing the winter inversion layer that traps the city's pollution and dust. Photo: Kunda Dixit

Our editorial this week says: "The least harmful way forward now is for the opposition to join an election government, let Prime Minister Bhattarai continue if need be, and let a general and local election in May untangle this mess".

What are your thoughts on this statement?

Ramji Neupane tours Kathmandu showing crowds his calf with two noses and three eyes. Ramji believes he has been blessed with the animal while people queue to see the creature, believing it is the reincarnation of goddess Laxmi.

Check out this story about Gyani Deula, a flower vendor in Kamaladi, who has adopted 21 abandoned dogs. The article says that despite the fact that dogs are gods in Nepal, hundreds of mongrel puppies are discarded on the streets of Kathmandu every year.

We would like to hear from you. 

Is there a contradiction between importance of dogs in Nepali culture and the abandonment of street dogs?

Don't miss some Ass' words: 

"On behalf of all the animals who feel left out this Tihar, let me, as an Ass myself, assure them that they are not forgotten. Ours is an inclusive democracy in which all animules have equal right to be worshipped. So from next year's Tihar, by presidential ordinance, we shall also mark Rat Tihar, House Fly Day, the Day of the Vulture, the National Day for Monkeying Around, and, last but not leastest, Donkey Day."

Because of Mustang's harsh and windy winters when temperatures can plummet to minus 15 Celsius inside unheated classrooms, schools have to send students down to Pokhara for the winter. Like the geese overhead that honk their way down migratory routes south along the Kali Gandaki, entire schools relocate for the four months till March. 

What is your opinion about education in remote areas in Nepal?

We continue to highlight the state of architecture in Kathmandu. Now it is the turn of Swati Pujari, in her column she says that the ambient space of the city is a cluttered and intermixed mish-mash: history and heritage rub shoulders with a non-descript globalised look.
link_name: Time travel in Kathmandu -  Nepali  Times

status_message: WRITING ON THE WALL: A Congress activist paints a message calling for elections in Bhotahiti on Tuesday morning. Photo: Min Ratna Bajracharya

Our editorial reflects on the US presidential elections this week and the great joy over the victory of Barack Obama. Even though the outcome of America's elections didn't really matter to Nepal either way, "this could be our way of showing support for democracy at a time when there are no signs here of elections any time soon?", it explains.

What are your ways out of the current political situation?

What are your thoughts of the statement: "Kathmandu's hideous urbanisation"?

Our journalist Anurag Acharya writes from Baglung and explains that the democratic deficit, the budget paralysis, and the fact that there have been no local elections for 12 years have seriously impacted development and the community spirit that this country was once famous for.

Do Nepalis tend to be pessimistic rather than optimistic about the daily life and the future?

status_message:
Han Suyin the author of the novel that inspired the Hollywood film 'Love is a Many Splendid Thing', died at 95 last week in Switzerland. 

She was well known in Nepal for her book 'The Mountain is Young' which became a best-seller because of its erotic passages. After 54 years of its publication, the book still sells well at Pilgrims and Mandala book stores in Kathmandu.

What is your opinion about the book?

Photos: Kunda Dixit.

The United States Geological Survey's Earthquake Hazards Program confirms that the epicentre lies across the Nepal-China border near Chongdui in China.

Nepal's leaders had promised the people they would have a deal to break the deadlock before the Dasain deadline. It didn't happen. Now they are promising a deal 'by Tihar'. Is it just a lack of political will or are there other reasons that a deal has not been reached yet?

status_message: KUMARI MOMENT: On Thursday Indra Jatra showed us officially the beginning of Dasain. Late in the evening, the living goddess Kumari did her traditional chariot procession in Hanuman Dhoka. Photo: Min Ratna Bajracharya

Joint families with grandparents, parents, uncles, aunts, and cousins all living under the same roof were the norm in Nepal till even a decade ago. Older members were respected and valued, and played a vital role in the transfer of knowledge, skills, and traditions. But today thousands of elderly Nepalis find themselves abandoned. What do you think is causing this rupture in our social values?

status_message: Most neighbourhoods in Kathmandu have no mains, and those that have pipes have no water. The lucky ones get water for only one hour every three days. What could be some solutions to the capital's chronic water crisis?

status_message: A Sita Air Dornier 228 flight from Kathmandu to Lukla crashed early today morning right after takeoff, plunging into a river near the runway, killing all 16 passengers and 3 crew members. Most of the passengers are said to be trekkers on their way to Mt Everest Base Camp
link_name: Nepali Times | The Brief  » Blog Archive   » Air crashes: 114 killed in 6 years

status_message: TOURISM DAY: Ascetics or as we know them in Nepal, sadhus, are a big attraction for tourists. Today, sadhus and travellers were both happy to meet each other at Kathmandu Durbar Square and remember Tourism Day.

Matthew Wittich took this photo outside of Pashupati during Shiva Ratri. He explains that children were holding a rope across the road to extract tolls from passing motorists. "I snapped this shot just as the boy was demanding a Rs 2 fare from the motorcyclist", he explains.

status_message: Follow the link and you can read the Expedition in Manaslu blog...

TRAGEDY ON MANASLU: A foreigner is rescued at Manaslu Base Camp after an avalanche swept away climbers and their camps on Sunday morning. According to media reports 12 people have been rescued and nine are feared dead. Courtesy: Simrik Air

In the past few years trees, public toilets, water fountains, parks, and traditional rest houses have slowly faded from the landscape of Kathmandu's memory, explains the article. 
Are they important part of Kathmandu or it is necessary that they disappear to modernise the city? tell us your thoughts.

SHOPPING MOOD: Early in the morning today the market near Ason was already crowded. Everybody wants to look good in this time of festivals and vendors know it. Good prices and variety of items are available for any kind of customer. Photo: Min Ratna Bajracharya
Censorship is a slippery slope. If you start selecting what is not acceptable, where do you draw the line?
What do you make of the decision to go into new elections in April? Do you think a fresh mandate can lift the country out of the deadlock or is it just another excuse to buy time?

After being separated from their homeland 20 years ago, many Bhutanese refugees resettled in the West are now separated from their families. Do you think host countries should respect the humanitarian need to keep families united?
link_name: Huddled masses yearning to rejoin families -  Nepali  Times

status_message: THREE Fs: This time of the year we enjoy the three Fs: Fab Festival Feasts and we see it everyday in Kathmandu. Last night on the occasion of Chatha (Lord Ganesh's bday) worshipers offered 'Samey Baji' (traditional Newari food) at Maru Ganeshthan. Photo: Min Ratna Bajracharya

This is a hot topic: 
Have you been a victim of corruption or bribe in Nepal? (If you don't want to post your comments here, send us your experiences to juanita@nepalitimes.com subject: Corruption)

HARD LIFE: Every day Manbahadur Buda, 57, walks the streets in Thalco, near Thamel, delivering metal containers. Not even Monsoon rains stop him to earn his Rs 200 per day to sustain his family. Photo: Min Ratna Bajracharya

LADIES IN RED: Women gather and dance together during the Tij festival at Pashupatinath, Kathmandu, today. In this festival, women fast for their husbands for better health and prosperity. Photo: Bikram Rai

status_message:
Saraswati Adhikari receives more than 130 trainees every year from different corners of the world to learn about organic farming, agro-biodiversity, and permaculture. She grows 160 plant species like medicinal herbs, rice, vegetables, and fruits, including the less common ones such as coffee, kiwi, and avocado.

http://www.nepalitimes.com/issue/2012/09/15/LifeTimes/19630

status_message:
Our editorial this week is about a still prevalent practice in this country: female foeticide. Every year in Nepal 50,000 unborn babies are aborted after parents find out through ultrasound scans that they are girls.
 
The real culprit for Nepal's female genocide is patriarchy in all its deplorable manifestations, says the editorial. Do you agree?
http://www.nepalitimes.com.np/issue/2012/09/14/Editorial/19627#.UFM1d41lTlc
link_name: Slaughter of our unborn daughters        -  Nepali  Times
