Agni Air's 9:40 am flight to Jomsom crashed 400 metres north west of the airport. The plane lost control while trying to land and went on to hit the face of a nearby hill. The flight was carrying 18 passengers and 3 crew members. 16 passengers were Indian nationals, while the nationality of the other 2 foreigners is not known yet. 

15 deaths have been confirmed so far. Out of the survivors, the air hostess and two passengers have been taken to Gandaki Hospital in Pokhara. Three others (one Indian adult and two Indian children) are being air lifted to Pokhara's Manipal Hospital.

Agni Air's 9:40 am flight to Jomsom crashed 400 metres north west of the airport. The plane lost control while trying to land and went on to hit the face of a nearby hill. The flight was carrying 18 passengers and 3 crew members. 16 passengers were Indian nationals, while the nationality of the other 2 foreigners is not known yet. 

15 deaths have been confirmed so far. Out of the survivors, the air hostess and two passengers have been taken to Fishtail Hospital in Pokhara. Three others (one Indian adult and two Indian children) are being air lifted to Pokhara's Manipal Hospital .
BREAKING NEWS: Agni Air flight from Pokhara to Jomsom, crashed while trying to land at Jomsom Airport. Details yet to come.

status_message: We recently re-introduced comments in our site due to popular demand. Feel free to move the conversation there, or continue here, or both. Happy reading. We look forward to hearing your thoughts.
The budget will be endorsed by tomorow, but our challenges are not over. Read Prashant Jha's article for a Reality Check.

WE WANT TO HEAR FROM YOU: Gadhimai Mela begins today, where more than half a million animals will be sacrificed. Is it any different than killing 50 million turkeys for Thanksgiving in America every year?

Usual Friday goodies + 2 new blogs (ok one is new-ish) on Nepali Times today. Bookmark for you: www.nepalitimes.com/blogs

Sunday reading: Yogi Kayastha left Kathmandu for a life in Humla. He writes about his experiences in Bcoming Humli.

We are very excited to announce the launch of a travel blog - EAST WEST with Kunda Dixit - on our website. We hope you will visit the blog and contribute to discussions there. It goes without saying, please be respectful to each other in your comments, and refrain from personal attacks. Happy Reading!

status_message: Ram Bahadur Bomjon, the 'Boy Buddha of Bara' who gained world renown after he meditated in the hollow of a tree, ostensibly without food and water for six months in 2006. He disappeared mysteriously then, and is now living in the jungle near Ratnapuri. We like his new look. :)
Sunday reading: Kunda Dixit's analysis on how Nepal is getting entangled in New Delhi's Sinophobia
If you haven't heard already, the Maoists called off their plan to declare autonomous provinces. Story below:

"We are not looking for any additional business," ex-UNMIN deputy Samuel Tamrat says, as United Nation-ers gather in New York today to discuss Nepal. We want to know what you think of UN's role in Nepal.
Weekly preview: Bardiya reaps rewards from Chitwan resort closures. There will be tigers, and art, and ton more exciting stuff on tomorrow paper. Happy reading!
555 fans! woo hoo!

status_message: Kathmandu airport blockade called off:
Maoists plan to declare autonomous federal states during the current phase of protests. A columnist (link below) argues federalism isn't a quick fix. What is your opinion?
We are tickled by the fact that Nepali cabinet has decided to hold a meeting on Mount Everest as Ass suggested last week:
Maoists picketed govt. offices across the country today. Our columnist Prashant Jha asks: These protests may break the stalemate, but what comes after?
Old airports, new destinations! Tons of airlines stuff in this week's issue:
PM says: "No possibility of government change until constitution written, elections held." Exclusive interview:
Maoists threaten new wave of protests.
Political deadlock: deal or no deal?

Nepali Times reporter Dewan Rai travelled to his hometown Khotang, and took these pictures. We wanted to share them with you.
Food for thought: can daylight savings solve Nepal's loadshedding problem?
You saw it here first: sneak preview of this week's paper.
Still hot in Kathmandu? We think its because global warming is real. But do we need new technology or good leadership to solve this growing problem?
Last evening, Sujata Koirala was promoted as deputy PM. Will this affect Madhav K Nepal's govt?
Non-resident Nepalese Association's conference begins in Kathmandu tomorrow. Two guest columnists ponder whether Nepal needs NRNs? Link below:
Maoist leader Prachanda began his week-long visit to China today. Our columnist CK Lal argues: "Political parties in Nepal continue to compete for patrons outside Nepal, but India is still top dog."
Also, if you are in Kathmandu go listen to some jazz at Jazzmandu and some blues Himalayan Blues.

status_message: Because of the holidays, this week's Nepali Times will be published a day earlier--meaning Thursday. Ass and the rest of the team will be back after Dashain on Friday, 9 October. Enjoy the time off, if you have it.
Today's update: Death toll of the Maoist insurgency higher than previously reported.
Sunday promotion: We have a special report on women lawmakers. And, the spectacular image on the front page taken by Manoj Shrestha.
New issue, new columnist!
This story about Jhamak Ghimire from last week's issue is very inspiring, if you haven't read it yet. Look out for the new issue tomorrow.
If you are in Kathmandu this weekend, Film South Asia is hosting its seventh documentary festival. Let us know your favourites!
So it begins.
